And what about posession? To express possession in Gupapuyŋu, we shift from personal pronouns (Lesson 1) to possessive ones. And yes, they change slightly...just like in English! We don't say 'I fish' or 'Me fish' (ok maybe some of us bogans say that last one), but formally it is 'My fish'.

Singular, One person:
Ŋarraku → My
Nhuŋu → Your
Nhanŋu → Her / His

Dual, Two people:
Ŋalitjalaŋgu → Our (You and Mine)
Ŋalinyalangu → Our (Her / His and Mine)
Nhumalaŋgu → Your (Two)
Walalaŋgu → Their (Two)

Plural, Three people:
Ŋi/ŋalimurruŋgu → Our (Mine an Yours (all))
Ŋanapurruŋgu → Our (Mine and Theirs)
Nhumalaŋgu → Your (all)
Walalaŋgu → Their

And then we can simply apply the structure from Lesson Two:
- Dhuwala ŋarraku guya (This is my fish)
- Walalaŋgu dhuwali yothu (That is their child)
- Dhuwali gara nhanŋu (That is your spear)
